awd_titl_txt: Polytopes and Matroids in Algebra and Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
In the last few decades combinatorics has grown and matured immensely as a field, in response to the mathematical needs of modern computing and the computational needs of all fields of mathematics. In particular, combinatorics and geometry have benefitted each other tremendously in recent years, both by the ways in which they are connected directly, and by learning from each other?s philosophies and techniques. This project studies the discrete structure of algebraic and geometric objects, and the algebraic and geometric structure of matroids and polytopes. This interdisciplinary perspective offers unexpected and effective approaches to long-standing problems. This research program constitutes the academic backbone of a vibrant research and training collaboration among primarily undergraduate institutions in the U.S. and Colombia. Through research-based courses, vertically and geographically integrated research projects, and the biannual Encuentro Colombiano de Combinatoria, students participate in a truly international cooperation while making substantial scientific contributions to combinatorics. Since 2007 this initiative has trained more than 150 pre-Ph.D. U.S. students, more than half of whom are members of underrepresented groups in mathematics, and more than 50 of whom have gone onto Ph.D. programs. The initiative also serves mathematicians worldwide through the distribution of course videos, lecture notes, and research projects.

This project studies three interdisciplinary and interrelated research directions: 1. By studying the geometric structure of matroids, we obtain purely combinatorial results that seem intractable without the geometric perspective, and we establish foundational results in tropical geometry and combinatorial Hodge theory. 2. We measure polytopes of interest by recognizing that they are part of ?the right? family of polytopes, and finding a formula for the measure of all the polytopes in that family. The results have consequences in toric geometry and representation theory. 3. We explore the Hopf-algebraic structure of various families of polytopes. The resulting objects are useful in numerous combinatorial and algebraic applications, and they raise geometric questions of independent interest. At the heart of each of these three projects lies a configuration of vectors - usually a root system - that plays an essential role. The combinatorial theories of polytopes and (Coxeter) matroids are designed to study such configurations, and the powerful toolkit that they offer is the unifying thread of this project. Solutions to the proposed problems will have a strong impact in combinatorics and discrete geometry, and will further our understanding of central questions in algebra and geometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT.

This interdisciplinary project studied questions at the intersection of combinatorics, geometry, and algebra. The project consisted of three interrelated research directions.

A. Geometry of matroids
Tropical geometry takes curved geometric objects that are difficult to analyze, and 'tropicalizes' them into discrete objects built from polyhedra. One then hopes to gather information about the curved object from its tropical counterpart. This has been done successfully in several different settings. We applied the reverse strategy: starting with a combinatorial object (a matroid or a root system), we constructed a tropical model for them, and used machinery from geometry to obtain interesting combinatorial consequences. 

Highlights: A1. Foundational developments of "tropical Hodge theory", a new field of combinatorics inspired by algebraic geometry. We proved that the Hodge property on a polyhedral space only depends on the geometry, not on the combinatorics. These new tools allowed us, and several other authors, to prove several decades-old conjectures in matroid theory. A2. A new understanding of the beautiful but intricate Chern-Schwartz-MacPherson cycle of a matroid, as a shadow of a much simpler cycle in the "conormal space", a richer geometric model of the matroid. A3. An elegant formula for the algebraic complexity of the "tropical root surfaces" associated to a highly symmetric collection of vector called a root system.

B. Measuring polytopes
Submodular functions are of great importance in optimization because they model situations with "diminishing returns", where the added value of a contribution becomes less impactful as the total value increases. These functions correspond precisely to the ways of "generalized permutahedra" (GP), the deformations of the beautifully symmetric permutahedron.

Highlights: B1. An extension of this correspondence to the next most natural family of symmetric polytopes: the Coxeter permutahedra. This has many consequences for combinatorial and optimization problems with underlying symmetry. B2. The discovery and combinatorial analysis of two related polytopes: the "harmonic polytope" and the "bipermutahedron". They both live in dimension 2n-2 and have 3^n-3 walls. They have  (n!)^2(1+1/2+ +1/n) and (2n)!/2^n vertices, respectively. We gave a formula for the volume of the harmonic polytope, and for the number of faces of the bipermutahedron, as well as numerous combinatorial, geometric, and analytic properties.

C. Hopf algebraic structures on polytopes
In combinatorics, it is often very useful to study discrete objects by (i) revealing their internal algebraic structure, or (ii) modeling them as polyhedra. In our 2016-2019 NSF we had combined these two strategies by discovering a new algebraic structure GP on polytopes, which has many structural features and applications including the solution to several open problems. We added a third angle to this study.

Highlights: C1. The discovery that (iii) studying the ways that geometric objects can be measured is also compatible with (i) and (ii). We found that the Hopf algebraic structure GP is compatible with the theory of polyhedral subdivisions of GP that we had studied in our 2010-16 CAREER grant.  We also proved a universality result that explains why GP are so ubiquitious in the theory of Hopf algebras. These theoretical result allowed us, and several other authors, to find many new ways of measuring matroids and generalized permutahedra.

 

BROADER IMPACTS.

This research program served as the mathematical backbone for Todxs Cuentan ("Everyone Counts"), a series of initiatives, activities, and publications led by the PI that seek to build and support an increasingly diverse, engaged, and active community of mathematicians that serves the needs of all sectors of society. The results of this work and lessons learned have been shared locally with science faculty across San Francisco State University,  nationally through programs like the MSRI-UP summer research program for underrepresented groups and the Latinx Mathematics Research Network, and internationally through articles and profiles in prominent publications like The Atlantic and the BBC.During this three-year period, the project provided direct research opportunities to 13 students and 15 junior faculty, the majority from underrepresented groups. The PI directly advised one postdoc, 2 PhD student, 8 Master's thesis students, and 3 undergraduate researchers; they were all involved in research projects which were or will be submitted for publication. Additionally, 21 undergraduate and Master's students carried out miniresearch projects in combinatorics and algebra. More than half of the students were women or gender expansive, and more than half were members of US ethnic underrepresented groups.About 100 additional participants were involved in the project through their participation in the biannual Encuentro Colombianos de Combinatoria. Hundreds of others around the world are involved indirectly, through an online archive of videos in graduate combinatorics developed under this grant.
